DataElement.preferredName: Head and Neck Tumor Primary Location Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the anatomic site, a malignant neoplasm affecting the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas, was initially diagnosed.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Head and Neck Tumor Primary Location
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the primary location or site of a head and neck tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: For oncology, area of the body generally construed to comprise base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary):A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Information related to the anatomic site, a malignant neoplasm affecting the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas, was initially diagnosed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.: The portion of the pharynx between the inferior portion of the oropharynx and the larynx.

Concepts.definition: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.
The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (or-o-FAIR-inks) The middle part of the throat that includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.: The cavity lying at the upper end of the alimentary canal, bounded on the outside by the lips and inside by the oropharynx and containing in humans the tongue, gums, and teeth.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.
The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

Concepts.definition: The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Oral Cavity Oropharynx Nasopharynx Hypopharynx Larynx Anatomic Site
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The cavity lying at the upper end of the alimentary canal, bounded on the outside by the lips and inside by the oropharynx and containing in humans the tongue, gums, and teeth.:(or-o-FAIR-inks) The middle part of the throat that includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.:The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.:The portion of the pharynx between the inferior portion of the oropharynx and the larynx.:The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.:Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.
The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.
The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.
The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.
The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.
Named locations of or within the body.
